newsitem.title: MEXICO: Mexico outlines pension fund operation rules.
newsitem.headline: Mexico outlines pension fund operation rules.

text.p: Mexican authorities on Thursday outlined the rules that will govern the country's new private pension fund system set to start next year.

Officials expect the soon-to-be privatized pension fund system to accumulate 30 billion pesos in 1997 and account for 40 percent of gross domestic product (GDP) in 25 years and create a big pool of savings for the economy.

Companies that manage pension funds, known as Afores, will have to begin with working capital of at least 25 million pesos, according to rules published on Thursday in the official gazzette. The investment funds themselves must begin with at least four million pesos in capital, the rules said.

During the first four years of the pension fund system, each Afore will be limited to a maximum 16 percent market share. After the first four years, government regulators will annually set the market share allowable for each Afore.

Rules said companies interested in setting up a pension fund for next year will need to register with Mexican authorities before October 18. The government's regulatory body, Consar, will announce which firms have qualified to start operations next year on December 3.
In the past few months, dozens of foreign companies have flocked here seeking partners for the privatized system.
